From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
Subject: Re: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO 2007
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=xOAFxBx3DG6QdWYb8h0LsFgxiGrbJ1pUqkNZT9TbOCaPkhJdGfBG
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Kirk, I've been having similar problems where a message I post never 
shows=
 up.  I think yahoo is having issues.  I suggest that anyone who 
posts thr=
ough online forms make a copy of your message before 
sending it.

Anyway, =
I think what you are saying actually is the kind of answer I 
would have  h=
oped to hear to my question, or at least it is the kind 
of answer I might =
have expected if their answers had been more 
detailed.  

Yet I personally=
 would not really take the answer in that direction 
if I had been asked my=
 own question (and of course I am biased!).  
The problem is that I do not =
think that mechanisistic descriptions 
(e.g. how a gene is transcribed) are=
 necessarily the right level 
abstraction for explaining how complexity is =
represented and 
searched.  Don't get me wrong- understanding the actual me=
chanisms 
does provide clues to the underlying explanation, but they do not=
 in 
themselves capture it.  

It's easy to get into a debate on what an "e=
xplanation" actually 
means.  AI researchers usually hold a really high sta=
ndard for 
explanation, which is that a good explanation tells you how to 
=
implement something yourself.  So for example, if you have an 
explanation =
of intelligence, it should tell me how to build it.  If I 
can't do that, t=
hen it's not reaching the treshold.  AI is sometimes 
criticized for having=
 such an absurdly high standard for theoretical 
validation.  Nevertheless,=
 I think that I personally tend to 
sympathize with the implementation-cent=
ric mentality.  I want to know 
how to do it myself.

And I think that kind=
 of thinking leads to higher levels of 
abstraction.  Sure, there may be in=
 effect more than 30,000 genes, 
for a variety of physical reasons.  Yet th=
ere are even only 
3,000,000,000 base pairs in the entire human genome.  Th=
at is still 
magnitudes below 100 trillion.  Not that such an argument inva=
lidates 
the idea that information can be combined in different ways- of 
c=
ourse that is exactly what's going on- but the question is, how 
exactly?  =


And my thoughts like many in EC gravitate towards ideas in indirect 
enco=
ding, which has grown up mainly in EC.  Of course, for myself and 
my stude=
nts, this line of thought has culminated in the 
HyperNEAT/CPPN style of ex=
planation, which is that in effect 
regularities are discovered that can be=
 expressed as functions of 
space and thereby encode spatial patterns.  As =
those regularities 
evolve, they are elaborated upon, which at a high level=
 of 
abstraction means that they are composed with yet more 
functions.  Th=
e nice thing about such a process is that you 
can easily discover simple r=
egularities early (thereby addressing the 
issue of search, the second part=
 of my question), and they form a 
scaffold for future elaboration.  Furthe=
rmore, it creates patterns as 
a function of Cartesian space, which is what=
 you need to do if you 
are going to create something situated in a physica=
l/geometric 
universe.  The explanatory appeal of this idea, which is 
subs=
tianally more abstract than the nuances of RNA->protein encoding, 
is that =
you can actually implement it, so it's an AI-style 
explanation.

Of course=
, if it is a proper abstraction, the explanation must 
ultimately reduce do=
wn to the mechanisms of biology, which I believe 
it does.  In particular i=
n Meinhardt's "Theoretical aspects of 
pattern formation and neuronal devel=
opment" 
(http://www.eb.tuebingen.mpg.de/departments/former-departments/h-
=
meinhardt) you can see how genetic regulatory networks in biology in 
effec=
t encode chemical gradients into spatial patterns that form the 
basis of o=
ther more complex spatial patterns situated in the 
coordinate frames of th=
e original gradients.  The term I like to use 
is "a plan upon a plan upon =
a plan."

In any case, that is the direction I would go with answering such=
 a 
question myself, which is influenced by biology but not as physically 
=
mechanistic as biologists often prefer to be.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogrou=
ps.com, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@...> wrote:
>
> First off, I apologize if=
 this is a double post.  It appears that my
> previous message did not go t=
hrough or I may have sent it to the 
wrong
> address.  If someone out there=
 has received my previous message
> unexpectedly - oops!
> 
> Ken's initial=
 question of 30,000 genes determining a 1 trillion
> connection brain is in=
complete.
> 
> While there may be around 30,000 genes in our genome, don't =
forget 
the
> central dogma of molecular biology:  DNA -> RNA -> Protein.  =
Once 
DNA
> is transcribed to RNA, RNA is processed and can result in multi=
ple
> variants which can then lead to subtle differences in the translated
=
> proteins.  An example is the Retinoid X Receptors.  On particular
> subse=
t, i.e. RXR-alpha, has one gene but multiple isoforms resulting
> from RNA =
variants.  Each of these has subtly different activities 
with
> respect to=
 retinoid binding, DNA specificity, transcriptional 
control,
> etc.  This =
effectively amplifies the number of apparent genes we 
have.
> 
> Also, not=
 all genes are expressed in all cells.  Cells have somewhat
> specific cont=
rols over what genes are expressed, to what level they
> are expressed, and=
 when they are expressed.  This gives each cell 
type
> a different proteom=
e that specifies that cells behavior and 
function.  
> 
> Just to add to t=
he complexity, proteins will be influenced by the
> milieu in which the are=
 present.  For example, tamoxifen has been
> commonly used as an anti-breas=
t cancer agent due to its ability to
> antagonize the estrogen receptor, wh=
ich is required for growth of 
some
> breast cancer tumors.  In cervical ce=
lls, however, tamoxifen acts as
> an AGONIST.  Based upon the cellular cont=
ext in which the receptor 
is
> present, tamoxifen exhibited different role=
s.
> 
> The fractal analogy used in one of the replies is somewhat 
applica=
ble
> and I would extend this to an analogy with Steering Behaviors (as
> e=
xemplified by Craig Reynolds).  In both these systems you have a 
very
> si=
mple set of rules leading to very complex behaviors.  Given the
> complexit=
y of protein expression and its role in determining cell
> behavior, the re=
sulting set of highly complex rules provides a 
medium
> in which emergence=
 of brain and mind can occur.
> 
> -Kirk
> 
> 
> 
>
